description: Alteration of curtal, from Old French courtault (“which has been shortened”), itself from court (“short”) (from Latin curtus) + -ault

entries.meaning: (architecture) A scroll termination, as of a step, etc.

verbs.description: curtail (third-person singular simple present curtails, present participle curtailing, simple past and past participle curtailed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To cut short the tail of an animal
(transitive) To shorten or abridge the duration of something; to truncate.
examples: When the audience grew restless, the speaker curtailed her speech.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figuratively) To limit or restrict, keep in check.
examples: The current Israeli government has been working to curtail and eliminate critical voices within Israeli society in recent years, particularly those fighting to end the occupation and expose human rights violations against Palestinians and marginalized communities.
